Q4S1: The people, both campers and coaches
Q4S2:
The seeming increase in the quality of the playing and singing of the campers over earlier years. Some of this can probably be attributed to the longevity of
many campers.......because they've had more experience with this and are more comfortable performing and inspiring others.
Q4S3: The evolving nature of the camp.....it changes a bit from year to year,  and this is good!
Q5S1: I can't really think of any significant changes. I'm happy with it the way it is.
Q5S2: N/A
Q5S3: N/A
Q6: None
Q7: None.....I experienced an absence of frustrations this year.
Q9: As a veteran camper, I don't usually get these materials any more, so I can't really comment on this.
Q202a: Scott is always fun to be around.....either in a group coaching situation or a more personal one-on-one situation
Q203a: Steve is simply a fun guy to be around, and has such an awesome and extremely clean playing ability....a true champion.
Q204a: I had essentially no direct experience with Scooter during this particular camp experience, but know him well and have always enjoyed being around him and occasionally encounter him elsewhere.
Q208a: Joan is always such a positive and encouraging person to be around, although I had little or no direct coaching time with her this trip. We all adore Joan.
Q207a: "Yoda" is always a trip!  A good coach and lots of fun to be with.....a great sense of humor and very encouraging.
Q205a: Gilbert is so consistently and infectiously enthusiastic about jamming and coaching and lots of fun to play and sing with.
Q206a: Leigh is simply a very nice person to be around.....again, no direct coaching from her this trip, but I have enjoyed an introduction to bass playing with her in the past.
Q209a: Dee is very focused and very articulate in his coaching style. He cuts to the chase in a very direct way that is very helpful either one-on-one or in a group context.
Q201a: Very laid back, very competent player and very gentle coaching style. Those of us who encountered him in a coaching situation warmed to him veryquickly. Very accommodating in doing backup playing in groups.
Q210a: No experience with Julie, but very intrigued by her and enjoyed watching and hearing her play in a group.
Q211a: I was very impressed with this young man.....he is an awesome player who appreciates the playing and singing efforts of others and was fun to be around. I hope he gets to come back again. Actually, I feel the same way about ALL the coaches!
Q212a: I had little experience with Brandon, but he seems OK to me.
Q213a:
Again, no experience with Liam in a coaching situation, but have known him from his earliest experience with jam camp and have enjoyed encouraging his endeavors,
both at Jam Camp and at IBMA etc.
Q200a: Pete is the consummate pro at this and really knows what he's doing. He gets results. He can be a bit acerbic at times, but all in a good cause! We all owe him a lot for creating these camps which are so great at getting closet pickers out of that closet.
Q105:
I thought it was adequate to good.....perhaps not quite as imaginative as in the past years, and certainly not as much fun as when we had those 3 local mountain ladies
in charge, but no complaints.
Q14comment:
Even though this was the largest group ever, I thought this was one of the best camps ever, with a great group of people and a large and interesting staff of coaches that we really enjoyed. While we may have been almost rained off the Cabin Stage this year, it came off very well, in my opinion, and I received quite a number of positive comments from those who saw this year's performance. Although not everyone may agree, I rather liked having Pete choose the two songs we performed as it bypassed all the
frustration of having to vote and experience disappointments.
Q16: Nothing but my sincere thanks for providing this interesting and exciting opportunity allowing folks to get more involved in bluegrass....it's one thing to enjoy and appreciate bluegrass music, but quite another to feel comfortable in actually participating in it on a performance level.

Q208a: I wish I had more time with her to get more practice singing, with which I had very little prior experience.
Q207a: I didn't spend any time working directly with Keith but sat with him and talked during several meals and found him to be knowledgeable, funny and approachable. I hope to work with him some next year!
Q205a: Gilbert is open, positive and enthusiastic and was a great leader, I had one instrument session with him (mandolins and fiddles together) and he provided one insight to the mandolin fretboard that will be extremely useful to me in the future.
Q206a: Leigh worked mostly with my novice group and was nurturing and provided gentle direction to a group that was sometimes a little unwieldy and disorganized.
Q200a: I enjoyed his morning talks and leading the large group through songs after breakfast. He was only able to come down the hill for one session with the novices, which I found enlightening and challenging as well. I wish I could have had more time with him...
Q105: Food was totally fine, maybe a little better than I expected...
Q14comment: I will be back next year!

Q17:
It was the thrill of a lifetime to get up on stage and perform at MerleFest.
I was not aware of the "open mic" night Tuesday night and the Wednesday night performance in advance, please make them more clear in the literature, I regret not being able to participate in them.
This was a great experience for me and offer these comments with a sincere desire to help improve an already great process.  Thank you

Q5S1: Beak out instrumental  instruction by a couple of degrees of ability.  We had two coaches and novice to advanced campers in our mando class.

Q4S1: Opportunity to jam with new people.
Q4S2: Opportunity to interact with some amazing instructors; even 30 minutes resulted in some "aha!" lightbulb moment.
Q4S3: Learning new songs.
Q203a: This was my third year at this camp, but my very first having time with Steve. He's got amazing talent but so down to earth and able to translate that into something meaningful for everyone.
Q204a:
This was my third year at this camp, but my very first having time with Scooter.  He was a coach for our band one session (Chick Keys) and was generally helpful; didn't get in our way. He had some great stories!

I also bought a used mandolin from Scott while at the camp (guitar is my main instrument) and I sat in on the mandolin class taught by Scooter on the very last day. It was GREAT. I was brand new to the instrument, and there were intermediate and advanced folks also in the same group, and I think we all got something out of it.

Scooter was also the coach for a small jam group on my very last day - mostly advanced folks (the Up Cane Creek folks invited Chick Keys to join them) and he just let us go forth and have fun, but he still contributed.
Q208a: I had only passing interaction with Joan this year, and I missed that!
Q207a: Keith is such a gifted instructor. He was coach for the Chick Keys for a couple of sessions and we all learned so much. He would have just a small tidbit to share for an individual on an instrument, then suggestions for how we operated as a group.  For example, he helped us figure out how to incorporate dynamics into our group playing. I play to schedule some individual lesson time with him (via Skype) over the next few months. Awesome!
Q205a: I've been to at least 8 different camps with Gilbert and he was fabulous, as always. I joined the "fill in licks" session, and he showed everyone a neat "move up the neck" lick (chromatic) and did a great job a) showing us the lick on individual instruments then putting us into instrument groups to learn it; and b) showing us HOW to apply what we learned! We played a couple of parts of songs where we all got to try incorporating the lick. While we did learn one specific lick (well, 3 variations of the same lick), he also emphasize the overall idea of how/when to use licks. Just a great session.
Q206a: I had only passing interaction with Leigh this year, and I missed seeing her more! We were in one late night jam together and the group was advanced enough to try new songs, and hard songs! As always, Leigh was so supportive.
Q209a: I had only passing interaction with Dee this year. :-(
Q201a: I did not have any interaction with Cecil; not even sure I could pick him out of a line up!
Q210a:
Julie was friendly, but clearly a novice at being a coach. She coached the Chick Keys a couple of times, and no real insights for us, just general positive "sounds good!" feedback.  In at least two sessions, she was busy chomping her gum and seemed preoccupied; if I didn't know better she could have been mistaken for one of the teen campers who sometimes seem bored with us old geezers!

In the third session where she coached us, Gilbert showed up and we asked him to stay to just play banjo (as our banjo player was not available - long story). Gilbert did a great job just being the banjo player and not stepping on Julie's toes, and deliberately would say "I'm not the coach here, ask Julie!" In this scenario, Julie was a bit more engaged with our group and was more proactive in giving us feedback (and the feedback seemed on point). Kudos to both Gilbert and Julie in this situation.
Q211a: Zeb? Never heard of the guy!
Q212a: Brandon....sounds familiar but have no clue who this was.
Q213a: I wasn't in any sessions with Liam but that would have been a treat!
Q200a:
Pete gave our band some grief for spending time rehearsing instead of attending harmony singing. I get his point about deviating from the schedule, and we should have kept him informed. But it was the only opportunity to work with our "hired gun" banjo player. If we had known there was a special guest visiting during that time, we would have been happy to make a big effort to participate more in that session. He came down on us pretty hard.

But...then we got to have Pete coach our band later that day, and it was EXTREMELY helpful. Pete is so gifted as a teacher, and I've not had much time with him in previous camps. Lots of basic stuff, but also some nuanced instruction.

Overall, I am so grateful to Pete (and the rest) for his passion to spread the message about bluegrass and teaching people HOW to jam. It's changed my life. So while Pete can sometimes be a bit gruff, it's all still worth it. He's a quality guy, and gifted teacher, and his contributions to all of us adult learners is hard to calculate.
Q16:
This is my third year, and having 80 people felt like too many compared to 70-ish in past years.

I appreciate all the hard work that Pete puts into the camp and into ensuring we all have a positive experience.

Instructors are great, for the most part! Can you get Bob Menke and Alan Epstein for next year? They are great.

Q4S1: Teachers
Q4S2: Learning new techniques and building skills
Q4S3: My group
Q5S1: Wednesday felt like  a day of practice for the Jamboree.  In the afternoon I heard groups across the campus playing the same songs over and over.    I understand feeling nervous, stressed  and distracted about performing especially if one is a beginner and it is important to have time to prepare.    I missed the focus, direction, and  learning of the two previous  days - it almost seemed like camp was over Tuesday evening.
Q202a: Scott is a wonderful teacher!   Sensitive, funny and has the personality for teaching.  He listened and seemed to understand what I needed even when I found it difficult to explain it.    He's a gift to the camp.
Q203a: Steve is  great teacher!   He was  straight to the point,  provided  constructive criticism in an encouraging manner with faint praise,  and was delightful to be around.    He's "a keeper."
Q204a: There are some musicians who are naturally gifted as teachers.    Scooter (Scott) is a super nice person, knows his craft,  and is very present to his group.    I felt that he knew how to play an instrument so well it was difficult to explain it to students.  I felt in over my head.    I think he would be best with advanced students.

Q4S1: Teachers
Q4S3: Group
Q5S1: I felt that the focus for the  majority of the campers on Wednesday was practicing for the Jamboree and in many ways it was an all-day prep for the performance.  I understand the stress of performing and the need to practice.   I missed the focus and learning I experienced in the first two days.      I don't know that there is anything that can be done to change the vibe for the day - the performance is fun and a learning opportunity - I  wanted to be honest about how I experienced the day.

Q4S1: Getting to see the same students and instructors who come back every year. We're like family.
Q4S2: I'm impressed with how Pete takes the feedback seriously, and isn't afraid to change things from year to year.  Case in point:  eliminating the lengthy voting process for the two songs to do at Merlefest.  Here are some more:  the beginner bass class.  The dobro class.  The fiddle tune jam at 5:00.
Q4S3: The open mic and the jamboree, and especially the encouraging support from everyone there.  I love those evenings.  And the electives!
Q5S1: The tedious selection process for selecting jam groups on Monday morning.  The application clearly asks for our jamming experience, and Pete knows those of us who return every year.  I'd like to see the groups put in place before we arrive.  Of course there will be last minute changes due to latecomers, but the  process could be significantly streamlined.  My group was one of the last chosen, and we didn't get to start jamming until 11:00.
Q5S2: Some of the groups had members, first-timers who had self-designated "intermediate" but had not taken Pete's guidelines/rules to heart.  They were not prepared to lead songs and some said they didn't want to sing.  A lot of time was wasted while they flipped through song books trying to find a song, and then had to figure out the key.  Some of the coaches, if present, didn't move to correct the situation.  Perhaps mention could be made in the general session that anyone in the jam group could step up, take a leadership position, and suggest moving to the next person in the circle while the the unprepared person comes up with a song he wants to lead the next time around.
Q5S3: I feel we got mixed signals about the harmony singing class.  I thought it was optional.  I think it's vitally important for anyone who hasn't taken it or has a desire to take it, but for those of us who feel secure in our harmony singing, I would like to feel comfortable choosing another option.
Q6: A chord class for fiddle players.  We had some good players, but some had trouble leading songs because they didn't know the chords to the songs they wanted to sing, or they just wanted to do fiddle tunes and couldn't describe them to those who didn't know them.
Q7: The housekeeping aspects.  I could listen to Pete talk all day about bluegrass history, personalities, the music...  perhaps someone the other things might be edited.
Q9: I addressed this earlier.  People are told to come prepared to lead songs.  Doesn't necessarily happen.  Fines, perhaps?  (Just kidding)
Q14comment: Don't remember, but seeing you on the Cabin Stage probably had something to do with it.
Q16: I truly admire Pete's dedication and  devotion to the cause.  He changed my life.
Q17: Keith Yoder is a gem.  I didn't have him as a coach this year, but his enthusiasm, disposition, and willingness to help anybody who needs help is a great asset.  And his improv class is the best.

Q105: food was great,,,,fresh and delicious with wide variety
Q16:
Thanks for such a grand experience and for helping me to find a better path to playing music....I found that all the TAB i learned was not so directly useful to me

The entire program was exceptional but the unexpected surprise was playing live on stage at Merles fest...I had not really considered or envisioned that until we were on the bus headed to the stage.    That was a wonderful  and profound insight into the life of a performer, the bus ride to the backstage setting the mood and building excitement, waiting to go on stage and then playing in the rain to a huge crowd

I could see how a person could live for those moments and the exchange of energy.     As an introvert, I was happy to be a backrow backup and chorus player and I could imagine that those who took solos would be even more so elated by the experience.

I decided at camp that I was playing banjo for the wrong reasons and so I have switched to guitar and fortunate to have the guidance from the camp experience plus good friends and neighbors ( some from the camp) to work together and share music

Thanks for being an inspiration and for all the guidance and help

G

The mind set that you need to create to be on stage.

Q105: Not so good. Too much meat, limited salad bar, little vegetarian choices. Breakfast very limited. Not really healthy choices as has been in the past.
Q14comment:
I will be back next year.  I look forward to next years camp from May till next April
Wish the camp in Boomer was twice a year.
THANK YOU
Q16:
Pete,
Thank you so much for the confidence you have shown in letting me perform my little verse on stage. I know you were worried that I would screw it up.
I will tell you that I wanted to get it right to a large degree because of your desire for ME to get it right and to pull off a successful performance. I felt the power of your personality and musicianship behind me and so,  I think, did just fine .  I fully realize the support and good wishes of all the other jam mates and benefited from them.
Thank You.  See you next year if not sooner.                       Lou,    Your student and friend.
Q17: Jan Camp at Boomer , what I look forward to all year.

Q202a: Excellent teacher.   Patient, good listener and great sense of humor.   Thoroughly enjoyed working with him.
Q203a: Excellent teacher.    Provided constructive criticism with encouragement and humor.   Thoroughly enjoyed working with him.

Q4S1: Instrumental breakouts were great this year!  Good mix of instruction and working on fun songs in my bass group.
Q4S2: All instructors that I worked with were top-notch, including the new folks.  I had the opportunity to work with both Brandon and Cecil, and was really impressed with their contributions.
Q5S1: With 80 attendees there needs to be more pre-planning for jam groups.  There was a LOT of time spent on dividing attendees into the small jam groups, which felt unorganized and used a lot of time on the first day.  I know the task can be monumental, but it seems that most campers are returnees, thus there should be some knowledge of their skill levels.  Perhaps more specific questions could be added to the sign up sheet to help with that process.
Q5S2: 80 attendees is huge for this camp. Consider a lower maximum...
Q5S3: Seemed to be a great emphasis on performances over the last couple of days.  Maybe just have open mics on Tuesday and Wednesday instead of a "required" jam group performance.
Q6: Maybe mix up the jam groups a little more frequently.  I understand this can be a difficult task.
Q9: No changes needed here.  Good info included in all communications.

Q4S1: Great instructors, especially Gilbert Nelson
Q4S3: Options for learning new skills like the upright bass and harmony singing.
Q205a: Gilbert is a wonderful instructor. He keeps it fun, fast paced, encourages all students and gives good feedback. He facilitated jamming groups on the opening day, Sunday, before any classes started and on several evenings.
Q206a: Leigh and Gilbert make a great team.
Q209a: Dee was very helpful in getting my lead guitar playing skills moving forward.
Q201a: Cecil was a great harmony singing coach.
Q200a: Pete did a great job leading the program, keeping it on schedule and giving big picture instruction.
Q105: The food was good and met my expectations for a YMCA type camp. It was always timely and had a good variety over the 4 days.
Q16: I'm seeing the Wernick method being taught in more places around the country. A number of sessions are listed in the Bluegrass Today events calendar. It seems to be expanding nicely and helping to promote bluegrass jamming to a growing audience who might not have tried it otherwise. I think the bluegrass festivals can be a great source of new students. Thanks for what you are doing!

We had five fiddles going and it was great to see him start the tune off really slow and work in speed as folks caught on.

Q4S1: The friendly atmosphere and sense of everyone encouraging each other
Q4S2: The opportunity to jam a lot in small groups

Q5S1: Have someone whose specific job it was to organise and facilitate (eg the organisation of the small groups) so that Pete could be more free to teach and oversee. A few times there was confusion over who was in what group and it felt like that took time out of the actual sessions
Q5S2: For the coaches to have more of a directional and instructional remit when we're jamming. A few times it felt like they were just there to sit in and keep things moving, which was fine but sometimes would have appreciated more tips and advice on how we could sound better as a group
Q6: The electives were all so interesting it would be nice to be able to go to more than one over the course of the camp. Definitely would have liked more on improvisation, the session with Keith was great
Q7: Felt like we spent a lot of time harmony singing in the afternoons but maybe that's because it was often the same song.

Q4S3: The singing lessons

Q4S1: Keith, Scott, Gilbert as instructors/coaches.  The others we had (Julie) were good, but those three were outstanding.
Q4S2: The after-hours jams with the instructors who stayed around.
Q4S3: The flexibility  and willingness of Pete, Joan, and the staff to accommodate requests for changes as needed.
Q5S1: Make the harmony singing workshop elective, and keep it that way.  Don't expect campers to be there if they already know how to harmonize, and don't get upset when it is not well attended.
Q5S2: Have dessert at lunch!
Q6: Level-appropriate instrument instruction.  Maybe split large instrument instruction groups into two groups based on level?
Q7: Harmony singing as a stand-alone class.  Maybe offer it as an elective.
Q9: They were fine.
Q202a: Great ideas, very on-target with suggestions, and flexible.
Q208a: I always enjoy interaction with Joan, and value her input, even when she does not directly coach my group.
Q207a: Keith is one of the best instructors I've had in all areas. He is so knowledgable in so many areas, and is able to work with students at all levels, and make it fun!
Q205a: I have loved any instruction I've had from Gilbert.  He is the best at breaking things down and making learning so much fun, regardless of student level.
Q206a: Leigh is always so willing and positive with all her instruction.
Q210a: Julie gives good input, but not enough of it, maybe due to her relatively young age and experience coaching.  Hopefully, she will develop confidence and assertiveness as she gains more experience.
Q200a: For the most part, Pete seems to be easy-going and flexible, and when he provides input, it is welcomed, and based on knowledge and experience.  However, one size does not fit all, and he tends to apply pressure where it may not be needed.
Q105: It was very good, overall.  Good quality and selection.  I never went hungry!
Q14comment: I saw a flyer in the Artists tent at Merlefest many years ago, and always wanted to attend.
Q16: I thoroughly enjoyed camp this year.  It brings together a great staff, quality instruction, and chances for jamming and building friendships.  I will certainly be back, as many seem to do!

Q16:
Lots of returning jammers each year raise the level of the camp. However, in some ways it detracts from the learning.  I felt the classes were geared either novice or advanced.
Being a intermediate player, I felt a little lost in the open jams because they always gravitated to the highest common denominator.

Somehow it is always hard to get people to  break up a 20 person jam into smaller groups.

A few  times our jamming group was without an instructor.
Q17: Overall Wernick Jam camps are the BEST. I appreciate the fact that Pete is listening and open to suggestions and is totally willing to make changes.

He's a wonderful musician and I've enjoyed his breakout sessions in the past. I am sorry that he is battling cancer and admire him for coming to camp to help us.
Q209a: Dee was a big help when he coached our jam group. He gave some really good feedback and advice. To the point. We played song after song and the jam moved along quite nicely.
Q201a: Cecil was very patient and offered advice in a kindly manner. He was helpful to us all, but was especially helpful to the fiddle player who was trying to switch from classical to bluegrass. The jam moved along nicely.  Hope he comes back next year!
Q200a: As many times as I have heard Pete talk, I ALWAYS pick up new things to incorporate into my playing and singing. This year's harmony workshop helped me understand yet another nuance of harmony that I had not understood in previous harmony workshops at camp.

Q17:
I was frustrated this year the first day of my jam group when no one knew any songs! Peter does a great job sending out information ahead of time and a list of songs we should learn. It was frustrating to go around the circle and people would take 10 minutes to search for a song to sing in a book. That's why I think it might be a good idea to group the jams according to 1) lots of songs, 2) some songs and 3) first timers,

Love the camp! Overall, it was a fun and worthwhile experience!

Q4S3: Being around amazing musicians like Pete, Joan, Scott, Keith, etc.
Q5S1: The quality of coaching makes the whole thing work. The two new coaches I had seemed unsure of their role in the jam group. One was extremely laid back and seemed to add even more down time between songs/slow the momentum of the jam, the other accepted an invite to play along but we needed to be observed and offered suggestions, not another player.  Neither offered much by way of constructive criticism, although both were very nice and are good musicians. Maybe have them shadow Keith or Gilbert?
Q5S2: I need more practice in harmony singing with other people singing the same part before I'm ready for a trio, and I'm not the only one. Can you please keep a group lesson going alongside the trios for those of us who need to practice singing parts with other people on the same part? Or maybe try groups of six?
Q5S3: The amazing kids are one of my favorite parts of camp, but I struggled this year with kids in my jam group and instrument classes. It might be a good idea to make sure there's an experienced coach in jam groups where a kid is jamming for the first time, to help explain the ground rules and observe how they're doing. And the instrument class teachers need to be aware of issues like kids noodling while they're explaining or demonstrating, and take steps to correct it.
Q6: The electives are great. I wish there was a way to take more than one.
Q202a: More difficult to get through a group lesson when the group is 10 or more people, but appreciated what we worked on.
Q207a: Keith is an amazing coach; having him step in and coach my jam group saved the experience for me.
Q210a: Julie is very nice and capable and I'd be happy to see her back next year, but I think she needs a stronger sense of the leader's role in both the jam group and the instrument class.
Q211a: Zeb is very laid back. I'm used to more input from jam leaders, and more help keeping the momentum of the jam going.
Q105: It was not great, not nearly as good as the previous two years. Please bring back the good food!!!
Q16: Thank you, Pete.

Q4S1: Quality and variety of the coaches/instructors
Q4S2: Opportunity to jam with experienced pickers
Q4S3: Chance to learn to play the bass.
Q5S1: Improve the sound system.
Q5S2: Separate after- hours slow  jam.
Q5S3: Make sure every camper has at least 3 jam songs; and put together a comprehensive list of the songs, by camper.
Q6:
More work on finding the melody, and then building a break around the melody.
More optional choice activities.
Q9: Emphasize having 3 songs to jam.
Q207a: Learned a great deal from Keith and enjoyed working with him.
Q205a: Very positive experience with Gilbert. So much so that I am planning on taking some private lessons from him.
Q200a: Need to develop some new jokes. Missed some of the history of bluegrass.
Q16: Pete: Thanks for your continued encouragement. Thanks largely to you, I am seeing significant progress in my playing.
Q17: Some of the new instructors didn't appear well versed in Pete's jamming protocols, (tick-tick-tock-tock, etc.)

Q4S1: The level of experience of the instructors.
Q4S2: The fact that the instructors took whatever time was nessesary for everyone to understand what was being taught.
Q4S3: The fact that the instructors pushed you to go beyond what you thought your limits where.
Q5S1: Since it was my first time at jam camp, I don't know if I would change anything at this point.  I found myself learning on all levels, so how do you improve that.
Q6: I really enjoyed and got more out of learning how to solo.
Q9: N/A
Q202a: No classes with him.
Q203a: I took only 1 class, The History of Bluegrass, from him, but he was very knowledgeable about the subject.
Q204a: No classes with him.
Q208a: No classes with her.
Q207a: I didn't have any classes with him, but he did approach me and engage in conversation.  He was very personable and seemed interested in me being at Jam Camp.
Q205a: I was impressed with Gilberts knowledge of music and his willingness to push me beyond what I believed my limits to be.  His ability to draw people out of their shell is remarkable.  In my case it was singing, something I have not always been comfortable with in front of people I don't know.
Q206a: Leigh was very personable, easy to talk to, and patient.
Q209a: Dee took a lot of time working with students on picking out song melodies and developing runs for playing solos.  I really enjoyed his classes.  He was very motivational to me to keep going and improving my playing and soloing skills.  Dee is a great teacher!
Q201a: I had no classes with Cecil.
Q210a: I had no classes with Julie.
Q200a: I like the fact that Pete has a great deal of patience and thinks that everyone can sing.
Q105: I thought the food was great!
Q14comment: My nephew from. Boone attended Jam Camp last year and thought that I would like it, so he talked me into it.  Most fun I've had in years!
Q16: I had a great time after being apprehensive about it I'm glad I attended.  Thanks for having me.
Q17: I wish I had attended sooner.

Q4S1: Learning more music theory
Q4S2: Getting more comfortable talking to new people
Q4S3: Learning to take breaks
Q5S1: More Music less talking in jam sessions
Q5S2: Would like to learn more jam etiquette
Q5S3: Mix ages more in jam bands
Q202a: Good teacher, kept it simple
Q203a: I wish I had taken his class. I heard it was the best class at the whole camp
Q207a: Very friendly. Made me feel at ease.
Q200a: Very encouraging
Q16: PA system class was terrible. Sorry I used my time for it.

Q4S1: The meeting of friends from previous camps
Q4S2: The instrumental breakout sessions were excellent,  particularly bass instruction
Q4S3: seeing progress from year to year with the young jammers.  Also the white board with group assignments was very efficient and saved time.
Q5S1: put all  participants in new jam groups each day.   do not let groups jam only with the same people,  keep mixing the people.
Q5S2:
More instructors jamming with low level jammers in the evenings.   Gilbert and Keith did jam with lower ability levels.
These people need the time in good jams and sometimes they felt left behind in the evenings.
Q5S3: Some groups worked on their performance songs in all the sessions.   Some members of those groups were quite frustrated with the only one focus for the week.
Q6: History sessions possibly in the evenings.  Bluegrass has a very interesting history related to the culture.  People can feel part of the culture if they learn some of the culture.   Pete is great at the history and I missed that part.
Q7: Getting ready for the Wednesday night jamming groups.  Some worked only other performance songs for three days.  Had e band scramble at 6:00 and start to perform at 7:00 on Wednesday.
Q9: Encourage new jammers pick out melodies on their instrument by trial and error before they arrive and learn chords to fit them.
Q203a: Great comments in the jam coaching.  I took a private lesson.  Very good teacher.  Would not take money but he accepted fishing lures.
Q204a:
Made the beginners think about song leading.   Forces the best out of people.  Very knowledgeable and has great insights.
Spends time jamming with campers.
Q207a: Always coaching and very enrolling of people into jams.  Spent in jams.  Excellent instruction on bass.  A treasure for the camp.
Q205a: Spent evenings jamming with campers every night.   Could use five more coaches like him playing and leading jams at night.
Q209a: Excellent jam coach.  Fun to be around.  Has a lot of common sense advice to musicians.
Q201a: Great bass coaching and was a gem in jams during break time.  Has a lot of teaching experience and that was obvious.
Q212a: Excellent Bass Clinics.  very skilled at teaching a group and having us be successful with new material.
Q200a: Pete is strong at encouraging new jammers to do it right.  Particularly effective with young musicians who want to keep doing it their way and getting them to learn the function of the rules
Q105: Very adequate and certainly enough.  Salads were very good.  Beverages are the best.  desserts were too good.
Q14comment: Jam class at Merlefest by Pete in 2000
Q16:
Bridget and I owe our musical fun to Pete and Joan.

We missed Chris and Rick Saenz this year
